title: I Hate Golgappas And It's Time People Stop Shaming Me For It
text:
I Hate Golgappas And It's Time People Stop Shaming Me For It

I Hate Golgappas And It's Time People Stop Shaming Me For It

You’re penalised for three things in this country: For not liking Bollywood, not wanting to become an engineer and, the most common one, hating golgappas.

You mention the words ‘dislike’ and ‘golgappas’ in the same sentence and people lose their shit, like when you tell an Instagram model that they aren’t a model. They mock you and tell you in detail how much you’re missing out on because aise kaise ho sakta hai, right?

How can anyone not like golgappas? I’m sorry to burst your bubble of ‘Bhaiya aur teekha’ and ‘Sookhi papdis’ but it’s not exactly a very fine culinary invention.

Also, it is absolutely okay to dislike things other people are fond of but for some godforsaken reason, hating on golgappas doesn’t go down well with people; just like golgappas don’t go down well with my digestive system (read: diarrhoea).

Ever since I was a kid, the smell and the taste has repulsed me to the point that my friends stopped hanging out with me because I would present them with facts about the dish, facts that prove how unhygienic the dish is.

Aur ek toh har state mein naam change ho jata hai par hygiene level woh hi rehta hai. No thanks, but I'm not a big fan of IBS.

“How can you not like golgappas man? Are you even Indian?” “There is something wrong with your taste palette.” “Golgappas are the best. You’re a weirdo.”

These are just some statements that I’ve been attacked with all my life. Okay, first of all, can we stop treating the fried hollow ball from hell like it’s our national dish? Secondly, not liking golgappas doesn’t make me a weirdo. It just means I value my stomach’s well-being more than others.

To be honest, it’s not even just the hygiene I’m concerned about. I mean, not knowing where all the 'teekha pani' comes from and the dirty hands of the golgappa-seller are secondary issues, of course. But I find the whole concept of the dish repulsive. It’s like I’m the only active member of the ‘I hate golgappas’ club.

I’m sorry if my taste buds don’t find a fried ball of atta filled with questionable, flavoured water delectable but don’t penalise me for it. Ek toh itni anxiety hoti hai khaate-khaate. There’s a golgappa in your mouth, one in your hand and the guy already has the next one ready. I’m sorry but life did not prepare me for this.

The way golgappa lovers come to attack me when I diss the dish is like they are part of a cult.

No thanks, but the devil of 'atta/sooji' forgot to send me an invite, and I think I’m good.

Aur ek toh galat jagah pe galat naam lelo toh aise upar chadh jate hain jaise ki Oxford dictionary mein added hai yeh words. “It’s not golgappa here okay? It’s phuchka!”

Jeez, relax. Jo bhi ho, hai toh inedible. Not just the people, even the golgappa-seller judges me like I’m missing out on his fine supply of India’s favourite snack. "Madam, aapko nahi chahiye?" So, while my friends line up next to the stall like people line up at Rajiv Chowk, I stand on the side, awkwardly waiting for them to get done with it.

The worst is when they constantly offer me every golgappa that is placed in their bowl and I shake my head every single time. Are they under the impression that I'll change my mind suddenly and decide to join in on the fun?

If I want to upset my stomach, I'd rather have some coffee. At least, I'll get a kick out of that.
description: Disliking golgappas doesn't make me odd. It just makes me someone who is concerned about the well-being of my bowel movements. Stop mocking me for disliking something everyone loves because guess what? We can do that and not be labelled as 'weird'!!!
